deliberation: Considered whether שׁוּב ('return') and נוּד ('waver/wander') are purely spatial or function as covenantal metaphors. Determined that both verbs are used figuratively for repentance and steadfastness, so there are two distinct metaphorical expressions.

instances.english_text: If you return, O Israel ... If you return to Me
target: Israel’s act of repentance / restoration of covenant loyalty
vehicle: physically returning to a person or place
ground: coming back from estrangement to proper proximity and relationship
posture: YHWH’s gracious invitation framed as a way back to Him
instances.explanation: Repentance is conceptualized as a physical return to God, mapping covenant faithfulness onto spatial nearness. This is also an idiomatic use of שׁוּב in prophetic calls to repentance.

instances.english_text: And do not waver
target: Israel’s constancy in allegiance to God
ground: unstable movement corresponds to vacillating loyalty
posture: warning against half‑hearted or fluctuating repentance
instances.explanation: Covenant instability is depicted as physical wavering or wandering, a conventional metaphor for unfaithfulness.

deliberation: Looked for overt imagery. The verse is mostly legal-religious. Noted that 'by you' as the source of blessing and boasting uses Israel as shorthand for its God and covenant status, functioning as metonymy in two parallel cola.

instances.english_text: Nations shall bless themselves by you
target: the nations’ experience of blessing associated with Israel’s God and covenant
vehicle: invoking Israel ('you') as the formula or channel of blessing
representative nation-name used for its God/covenant
ground: Israel embodies and represents access to YHWH’s blessing
association of people with their deity and privileges
posture: promise that Israel’s restored fidelity will make it a paradigm of blessing for others
instances.explanation: “You” (Israel) stands metonymically for Israel’s special relationship with YHWH; blessing ‘by you’ really means by the God and covenant you represent.

instances.english_text: And by you they shall glory/boast
target: nations’ pride and rejoicing in connection with Israel’s God and salvation
vehicle: boasting ‘in’ Israel as an object of pride
ground: Israel’s restored standing becomes the reference point of others’ pride
associative honor transferred from Israel to those linked with it
posture: depicts a future in which Israel’s story is the template of praiseworthy blessing
instances.explanation: Boasting ‘in you’ uses Israel metonymically for the salvific reality it mediates; the nations’ glory lies in sharing Israel’s God-given status.

deliberation: The whole verse uses agricultural language. Asked whether this is literal agronomic advice or figurative for inner readiness. In prophetic context (vv.1–4) it clearly functions as a repentance image: hearts as soil, word as seed, sins as thorns.

instances.english_text: Break up the untilled ground for yourselves, and do not sow among thorns
target: the spiritual and moral condition of Judah and Jerusalem, and their response to God’s word
vehicle: untilled soil being broken up and seed sown, but not among thorns
ground: just as ground must be prepared and cleared of thorns to bear fruit, hearts must be prepared and cleared of sins to respond fruitfully
removal of obstacles for fruitful outcome
posture: urgent exhortation to interior transformation before it is too late
instances.explanation: Inner repentance and readiness for God’s message are portrayed as cultivating fallow ground and avoiding sowing seed among thorns.

deliberation: Identified two strong figurative complexes: (1) ‘circumcise yourselves to YHWH’ and ‘remove the foreskins of your heart’—a metaphorical extension of physical circumcision; (2) divine wrath depicted as an unquenchable fire, explicitly marked with a simile particle כְּ.

instances.english_text: Open your hearts to GOD [lit. Circumcise yourselves to YHWH] and remove the foreskins of your heart
target: the people’s inner stubbornness and need for radical repentance
vehicle: the surgical removal of foreskin in covenantal circumcision
ground: just as circumcision cuts away flesh as a sign of covenant belonging, inner circumcision removes hardness that resists God
painful removal leading to covenant fidelity
posture: demand for deep, not merely external, covenant loyalty
instances.explanation: The physical rite of circumcision is applied metaphorically to the heart, urging the removal of inner ‘foreskins’—stubbornness and sin. It is both metaphor and a conventional prophetic idiom, and involves a conceptual extension of a ritual sign (hence marked as ‘other’ for conceptualized ritual).

instances.hebrew_text: פֶּן־תֵּצֵ֨א כָאֵ֜שׁ חֲמָתִ֗י וּבָֽעֲרָה֙ וְאֵ֣ין מְכַבֶּ֔ה
instances.english_text: Lest My wrath break forth like fire, and burn, with none to quench it
target: the experience and effects of YHWH’s punitive anger
ground: both wrath and fire are intense, consuming, and hard to stop once unleashed
posture: warning of catastrophic, irreversible consequences of continued wickedness
instances.explanation: Divine wrath is compared explicitly to fire and then described as burning with no one to quench it. The simile (‘like fire’) shades into an extended metaphor and uses hyperbolic language (‘none to quench it’) to stress the severity of judgment.

deliberation: Commands to proclaim, blow the shofar, assemble, and go to fortified cities all fit a literal military-mobilization context. No clear metaphors, similes, or personifications beyond standard military language.

Examined whether ‘evil from the north’ is merely directional or symbolic. In Jeremiah the ‘north’ functions as a cipher for the imperial invader (Babylon, etc.), a geographic metonymy for a political power. That is a distinct figurative device.

instances.english_text: For I bring evil from the north
target: the invading imperial power that will devastate Judah
vehicle: cardinal direction as stand‑in for its inhabitants and powers
ground: the invader historically approaches from the north, so the region stands for the agent of disaster
stable association of direction with a specific threat
posture: announcement of divinely sent disaster through a known threat vector
instances.explanation: ‘The north’ functions metonymically for the northern empire that will bring calamity; the direction stands for the invading power itself.

deliberation: The verse compares the invading conqueror to a lion emerging from thicket and calls him ‘destroyer of nations.’ This is a classic zoomorphic war metaphor; the rest of the verse (desolation, no inhabitant) can be literal or hyperbolic description, but the lion image is clearly figurative.

instances.hebrew_text: עָלָ֤ה אַרְיֵה֙ מִֽסֻּבְּכ֔וֹ וּמַשְׁחִ֣ית גּוֹיִ֔ם נָסַ֖ע יָצָ֣א מִמְּקֹמ֑וֹ
instances.english_text: The lion has come up from its thicket; the destroyer of nations has set out, has departed from its place
target: the invading king/army that will devastate the land
vehicle: a lion leaving its thicket as a ‘destroyer of nations’
ground: both lion and conqueror are powerful, fearsome, and lethal, attacking and tearing prey/peoples
posture: depicts the enemy as terrifying and unstoppable to intensify the warning
instances.explanation: The foreign conqueror is metaphorically portrayed as a lion emerging from cover to destroy prey, highlighting his ferocity and the helplessness of the victims. The title ‘destroyer of nations’ is also hyperbolic in scope.

deliberation: Most of the verse is literal cultic mourning response (sackcloth, wailing). The phrase ‘the blazing anger of YHWH’ uses the idiom חֲרוֹן אַף, literally ‘the burning of (his) nose,’ a conventional anthropomorphic metaphor for intense anger and its persistence.

instances.english_text: For GOD’s blazing anger has not turned away from us
target: the intensity and persistence of YHWH’s wrath against the people
vehicle: a burning, flaring nose/face that does not turn back
ground: heated facial features correspond to intense, ongoing anger
bodily heat as index of wrath
posture: underscores that judgment is still active and unresolved despite mourning rites
instances.explanation: חֲרוֹן אַף (‘burning of nose/anger’) is an idiomatic anthropomorphic metaphor that pictures God’s wrath as hot, burning facial heat that has not turned away.

deliberation: Looked for imagery. The key expression is ‘the heart of the king…shall perish,’ which uses ‘heart’ as the seat of courage/understanding. This is standard Hebrew metonymy/idiom for loss of resolve or wisdom, not literal cardiac death.

instances.english_text: The mind [lit. heart] of the king and the mind of the nobles shall fail
target: the king’s and officials’ courage, decision-making, and composure
vehicle: the physical ‘heart’ conceived as center of thought and courage
ground: heart is culturally associated with understanding and resolve; its ‘perishing’ signifies collapse of those faculties
loss of center equals loss of capacity
posture: depicts total leadership disintegration under divine judgment
instances.explanation: ‘Heart’ stands metonymically for inner courage and wisdom; its ‘being lost’ figuratively describes the leaders’ mental and emotional breakdown.

deliberation: Most of the verse is propositional. The vivid phrase is ‘the sword has reached to the life/soul,’ where ‘sword’ stands for warfare and ‘reaching the life’ intensifies the threat beyond mere external harm.

instances.english_text: Yet the sword threatens [has reached] the very life
target: the mortal danger posed to the people by impending warfare
vehicle: a literal sword reaching all the way to a person’s ‘soul/life’
ground: warfare (sword) can cut down even to a person’s very life; here it signals danger to existence itself, not just discomfort
proximity of lethal force to core of being
posture: Jeremiah protests that despite assurances of peace, lethal judgment is actually imminent
instances.explanation: ‘Sword’ is a metonymy for war and judgment; saying it has reached ‘to the soul/life’ hyperbolically emphasizes how close and lethal the danger is.

deliberation: Hebrew speaks of a ‘clear/dry wind from the bare heights in the wilderness’ coming toward ‘the daughter of my people,’ explicitly ‘not for winnowing or cleansing.’ This is a destructive desert wind metaphor for judgment/invasion, and ‘daughter of my people’ personifies the nation as a vulnerable female.

instances.hebrew_text: ר֣וּחַ צַ֤ח שְׁפָיִם֙ בַּמִּדְבָּ֔ר דֶּ֖רֶךְ בַּת־עַמִּ֑י ל֥וֹא לִזְר֖וֹת וְל֥וֹא לְהָבַֽר
instances.english_text: A searing wind from the bare heights in the desert, on the way to the daughter of My people, not for winnowing or for cleansing
target: the destructive judgment/invasion coming upon Judah
vehicle: a dry, scorching desert wind that is too strong for useful threshing, purely destructive
ground: both the wind and the judgment are overpowering, harmful, and not purifying but devastating
posture: frames the coming event as sheer devastation rather than corrective discipline
instances.explanation: A destructive desert wind symbolizes God’s judgment; the note that it is ‘not for winnowing or cleansing’ stresses that this is not a gentle, beneficial process but unmitigated devastation.

instances.english_text: the daughter of My people
vehicle: a daughter belonging to someone, i.e., a young woman under a father’s care
ground: like a daughter, the people are dependent, vulnerable, and under YHWH’s care and authority
posture: expresses tender but pained concern for the people facing harm
instances.explanation: The nation is personified as ‘the daughter of My people,’ a familial metaphor highlighting vulnerability and YHWH’s parental relationship to them.

deliberation: This continues the ‘wind’ image from v.11: a ‘fuller wind than these’ coming ‘for Me.’ It is not meteorological reportage but a metaphor for an intensified act of judgment. The legal phrase ‘I will speak judgments with them’ may be courtroom imagery but is also standard idiom.

instances.english_text: A full blast [lit. a wind fuller than these] shall come for Me
target: the heightened, more severe phase of God’s judgment on the people
vehicle: a stronger, ‘fuller’ wind surpassing previous winds
ground: increased wind intensity corresponds to increased severity of judgment
posture: announces escalation: God will move from warning to full judicial action
instances.explanation: The ‘fuller wind’ continues the wind-as-judgment metaphor, marking an escalation in severity as God proceeds to execute formal judgments.

deliberation: Identified three linked comparisons: the destroyer’s ascent ‘like clouds,’ his chariots ‘like a whirlwind,’ and his horses ‘swifter than eagles.’ The first two form a storm-theophany cluster; the third is a distinct speed simile.

instances.english_text: Lo, he ascends like clouds; his chariots are like a whirlwind
target: the advancing enemy force and its military machinery
vehicle: cloud masses and a whirlwind storm
ground: the enemy’s approach is massive, overwhelming, and swift like storm clouds and a whirlwind
suddenness and irresistibility of a storm front
posture: evokes terror and inevitability, likening the invasion to a cosmic storm
instances.explanation: Cloud and whirlwind imagery likens the invading army to an overpowering storm front, highlighting its scale and destructive force.

instances.english_text: His horses are swifter than eagles
target: the speed of the enemy cavalry
ground: both horses and eagles can move quickly; eagles epitomize speed and agility
posture: underscores the futility of escape given the enemy’s speed
instances.explanation: The cavalry’s speed is exaggerated by comparison with eagles, a hyperbolic simile that conveys how impossible it will be to outrun the invader.

deliberation: Found two inner-life metaphors: (1) ‘wash your heart from evil’ treating moral cleansing as laundering; (2) ‘how long will your evil thoughts lodge within you’ conceptualizing sinful designs as guests dwelling inside.

instances.english_text: Wash your heart clean of wickedness
target: the inner moral state of Jerusalem (its ‘heart’)
vehicle: washing/laundering to remove dirt or stains
ground: as stains are removed by washing, so guilt and evil can be removed by repentance and divine forgiveness
transition from dirty to clean state
posture: urgent appeal to thorough inner cleansing, not superficial change
instances.explanation: Jerusalem’s moral reformation is portrayed as washing the heart, extending physical cleaning imagery to the inner life; a standard prophetic metaphor/idiom.

instances.english_text: How long will you harbor within you your evil designs?
vehicle: evil thoughts as guests lodging overnight within a person
ground: harbored guests and cherished plans both are kept inside and not expelled
allowing something unwelcome to remain within one’s space
posture: rebukes the voluntary retention of evil purposes, as though they were welcome lodgers
instances.explanation: Sinful thoughts are depicted as lodgers staying inside Jerusalem, highlighting intentional, ongoing accommodation of evil rather than accidental lapse.

deliberation: The verse simply locates a herald’s voice from Dan and Mount Ephraim, announcing calamity. This can be taken literally within the narrative/vision of approaching invasion; no strong metaphor, simile, or personification is required.

Considered whether ‘watchers’ coming from a distant land is figurative. In context these are besieging forces who literally ‘keep watch’ around cities (clarified in v.17). The verse itself uses straightforward military description without overt comparison language.
Here there is an explicit כְּ‑simile: invaders ‘like guards of fields’ surrounding her. This compares siege troops to agricultural field-guards who constantly watch their plots.

instances.english_text: Like guards of fields, they surround her on every side
target: the behavior and positioning of the besieging enemy around Jerusalem
vehicle: field-guards surrounding and watching their fields
ground: both besiegers and field-guards maintain constant, enclosing watch to control what goes in and out
posture: emphasizes the thoroughness and inevitability of the siege
instances.explanation: The invaders’ siege is likened to field-guards’ watch, a simile that underlines how completely Jerusalem will be surrounded and controlled.

deliberation: The judgment is described as ‘your evil’ that ‘is bitter’ and ‘has reached to your heart.’ The key figurative pieces are the taste metaphor ‘bitter’ for painful experience and the depth metaphor ‘reaching to the heart’ for penetrating suffering.

instances.hebrew_text: זֹ֤את רָעָתֵךְ֙ כִּ֣י מָ֔ר כִּ֥י נָגַ֖ע עַד־לִבֵּֽךְ
instances.english_text: This is your evil; it is bitter; it pierces your very heart
target: the painful consequences of Judah’s own wickedness
vehicle: bitter taste and something touching/reaching the heart
ground: just as bitterness is unpleasant on the tongue, so the judgment is deeply unpleasant; reaching the heart signals inner, profound impact
posture: explains suffering as self-inflicted and profoundly penetrating
instances.explanation: The people’s punishment is called ‘bitter’ and said to have reached ‘to your heart,’ using taste and depth metaphors to convey the severity and inwardness of the suffering.

deliberation: The verse is full of somatic language: ‘my bowels, my bowels,’ ‘the walls of my heart,’ ‘my heart moans within me,’ ‘my soul has heard.’ These expressions use internal organs metaphorically/idiomatically for intense emotional distress; ‘walls of my heart’ especially images the heart as a structure.

instances.hebrew_text: מֵעַ֣י מֵעַ֨י ... קִיר֥וֹת לִבִּ֛י הֹמֶה־לִּ֥י לִבִּ֖י
instances.english_text: Oh, my suffering, my suffering! [lit. My bowels, my bowels!] Oh, the walls of my heart! My heart moans within me
target: Jeremiah’s (or Zion’s) intense inner anguish at the coming war
vehicle: inner organs (bowels, heart) writhing, with ‘walls of the heart’ trembling
ground: inner organs are culturally viewed as seats of emotion; their imagined convulsions convey extreme, enclosed distress
inward physical agitation parallels emotional turbulence
posture: expresses overwhelming sympathetic pain at hearing war alarms
instances.explanation: Internal organs are used metonymically and metaphorically as the loci of feeling; the ‘walls of my heart’ hyperbolically portray inner life as a besieged structure shaking with fear.

deliberation: Identified (1) ‘disaster upon disaster’ as intensifying repetition, a hyperbolic idiom; (2) ‘my tents’ and ‘my tent cloths’ as a synecdochic/self-referential image for the speaker’s dwelling/people suddenly ravaged.

instances.english_text: Disaster upon disaster is proclaimed
target: the frequency and accumulation of calamities befalling the land
ground: stacking ‘breakings’ evokes a sense of continuous, compounded catastrophe
posture: stresses overwhelming nature of judgment events
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘disaster upon disaster’ is an idiomatic, hyperbolic way of saying that calamities keep following one another without pause.

instances.english_text: Suddenly my tents have been ravaged, in a moment my tent cloths
target: the speaker’s (or Zion’s) dwelling and community life
vehicle: tents and tent curtains being plundered
ground: tents represent one’s habitation and family; their destruction equals loss of home and security
destruction of housing symbolizes loss of community
posture: emphasizes the suddenness and totality of personal/national loss
instances.explanation: ‘My tents’ and ‘my tent cloths’ function as a synecdoche and metonymy for the speaker’s entire life and community, depicting their sudden ruin through the image of destroyed dwellings.

deliberation: The question ‘How long must I see the standard and hear the horn?’ can be read literally as ongoing exposure to military signals. No additional figurative comparison or personification is necessary, so I do not treat it as figurative.

Noted two rhetorical figures: (1) calling the people ‘foolish children’—a metaphor for moral immaturity; (2) ‘wise to do evil, but not to do good’—an ironic twist where ‘wise’ is applied sarcastically, a form of irony rather than literal wisdom.

instances.english_text: They are foolish children
target: God’s people in their moral and spiritual behavior
ground: like foolish children, the people are irresponsible, uncomprehending, and resistant to instruction
posture: rebukes the people’s stubborn ignorance as immature and culpable
instances.explanation: By calling them ‘foolish children,’ God metaphorically characterizes the people as morally and spiritually immature offspring.

instances.hebrew_text: חֲכָמִ֥ים הֵ֙מָּה֙ לְהָרַ֔ע וּלְהֵיטִ֖יב לֹ֥א יָדָֽעוּ
instances.english_text: They are clever [wise] at doing wrong, but unable to do right
target: the people’s perverse skill set in evil contrasted with their incompetence in good
vehicle: wisdom/skill language applied to acts of evil
ground: they expend intelligence on wrongdoing while being effectively ignorant of righteousness
posture: uses biting irony to expose how twisted their ‘wisdom’ is
instances.explanation: Calling them ‘wise to do evil’ is ironic and hyperbolic: the language of wisdom is sarcastically redirected to their capacity for wrongdoing, contrasted with their incapacity for good.

deliberation: The prophet ‘sees’ the land as ‘tohu va‑vohu’ and the heavens without light, echoing Genesis 1:2. This applies creation-chaos imagery to the post-judgment land—using the cosmogonic scene as a metaphor for total devastation.

instances.english_text: I look at the earth—it is unformed and void; at the skies, and their light is gone
target: the condition of the land and sky after divine judgment on Judah
vehicle: the pre-creation chaos of ‘formless and void’ earth and darkened heavens
ground: both scenarios depict a world in a state of formless ruin and darkness, prior to (or after loss of) ordered life
absence of structure, life, and light
posture: intends to shock by equating Judah’s devastation with a reversal to pre-creation chaos
instances.explanation: Language drawn from Genesis 1 (‘tohu va‑vohu,’ lack of light) is metaphorically reapplied to Judah’s judged land, hyperbolically portraying it as a return to primeval chaos.

deliberation: Mountains and hills are said to be ‘quaking’ and ‘rocking.’ While God can literally cause earthquakes, here it functions more as theophanic imagery: creation convulses in response to divine judgment, a personifying metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: רָאִ֙יתִי֙ הֶהָרִ֔ים וְהִנֵּ֖ה רֹעֲשִׁ֑ים וְכׇל־הַגְּבָע֖וֹת הִתְקַלְקָֽלוּ
instances.english_text: I look at the mountains, they are quaking; and all the hills are rocking
target: the immense impact of God’s judgment on the established order
vehicle: mountains and hills trembling and rocking as if terrified or unstable
ground: mountains symbolize stability; their ‘quaking’ signifies profound upheaval
even what seems most solid is shaken
posture: communicates the cataclysmic scale of judgment in vivid cosmic terms
instances.explanation: Mountains and hills are personified/depicted as shaking, a hyperbolic theophanic metaphor to show the radical disturbance of the created order by God’s judgment.

deliberation: The seer reports ‘no human’ and ‘all the birds have fled.’ Within the vision this can be read literally, but in prophetic rhetoric it functions as hyperbolic totalization—‘no one’ and ‘all birds’ to express complete desolation.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהִנֵּ֖ה אֵ֣ין הָאָדָ֑ם וְכׇל־ע֥וֹף הַשָּׁמַ֖יִם נָדָֽדוּ
instances.english_text: I look: no human is left, and all the birds of the sky have fled
target: the extent of depopulation and ecological disruption after judgment
vehicle: absolute absence of humans and flight of every bird
ground: claiming no people and all birds gone stresses that life as such has vanished from the scene
posture: heightens the horror of judgment by picturing an emptied, lifeless land
instances.explanation: ‘No human’ and ‘all the birds have fled’ function as hyperbolic totalizations to express the land’s utter desolation in the vision.

deliberation: Two possible figuratives: fertile ‘Carmel’ as ‘wilderness’ and the idiom ‘the heat of His nose’ for anger. The first may describe actual devastation; the second is a clear anthropomorphic metaphor for divine wrath, as in v.8, and is the stronger figure.

instances.english_text: Because of GOD, because of His blazing anger [lit. the heat of His nose]
target: the intensity of God’s anger that causes the land’s ruin
vehicle: a nose/face burning hot with anger
ground: a heated nose/face reflects strong anger; the image maps bodily heat to intensity of wrath
posture: attributes the devastation directly to God’s intense, personal anger
instances.explanation: חֲרוֹן אַף (‘heat of His nose’) is a stock anthropomorphic metaphor/idiom for fierce divine anger, used here to ground the land’s desolation in God’s wrath.

deliberation: The verse straightforwardly declares the land will be desolate, yet God will not make a full end. ‘Desolation’ is descriptive; ‘full end’ is conceptually standard. No distinct figurative images beyond normal abstract usage.
Found strong personification: ‘the earth mourns’ and ‘the heavens grow dark’ in response to God’s decree. The darkness also metaphorically connotes grief and doom.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־זֹאת֙ תֶּאֱבַ֣ל הָאָ֔רֶץ וְקָדְר֥וּ הַשָּׁמַ֖יִם מִמָּ֑עַל
instances.english_text: For this the earth mourns, and the skies are dark above
target: the cosmic-scale repercussions and universal sadness over Judah’s judgment
vehicle: earth acting as a mourner and skies becoming darkened
ground: mourning and darkness are associated with grief; depicting earth and sky thus communicates universal lament and foreboding
posture: underscores the seriousness and irreversibility of God’s resolve by giving it cosmic emotional resonance
instances.explanation: Earth and heavens are personified as mourning and darkening in sympathy with the judgment, using mourning and gloom imagery to express cosmic grief.

deliberation: Scene of flight at the sound of horsemen and archers is largely literal. The phrase ‘the whole city flees’ uses ‘city’ as metonymy/synecdoche for its inhabitants, since the built structures cannot flee.

instances.english_text: The whole city flees
target: all the inhabitants of the city fleeing from the invaders
ground: speaking of the city fleeing emphasizes that its people, in total, are running away
city stands for people who constitute it
posture: stresses the universality and panic of the response to invasion
instances.explanation: ‘City’ metonymically and synecdochically represents its inhabitants; describing it as fleeing is a concise, somewhat hyperbolic way to say that everybody is running for cover.

deliberation: The entire verse is an extended personification/metaphor of Zion as a woman adorned in crimson, gold, and eye paint to attract lovers, who nonetheless despise her and seek her life. This represents Judah’s vain attempts to win favor (alliances, cultic charms) in the face of inevitable judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאַ֨תְּ שָׁד֜וּד מַֽה־תַּעֲשִׂ֗י כִּֽי־תִלְבְּשִׁ֨י שָׁנִ֜י כִּֽי־תַעְדִּ֣י עֲדִֽי־זָהָ֗ב כִּֽי־תִקְרְעִ֤י בַפּוּךְ֙ עֵינַ֔יִךְ לַשָּׁ֖וְא תִּתְיַפִּ֑י מָאֲסוּ־בָ֥ךְ עֹגְבִ֖ים נַפְשֵׁ֥ךְ יְבַקֵּֽשׁוּ
instances.english_text: And you, who are doomed to ruin, what do you accomplish by wearing crimson, by decking yourself in jewels of gold, by enlarging your eyes with kohl? In vain you beautify yourself; lovers despise you, they seek your life!
target: Zion/Judah’s political and religious attempts to secure favor and protection (alliances, adornments)
vehicle: a despoiled woman adorning herself in luxurious clothing, jewelry, and cosmetics to attract lovers who now despise her and want to kill her
ground: just as a disgraced woman’s adornment cannot win back lovers who now seek her harm, Judah’s efforts to impress allies or gods cannot avert judgment
external beautification vs. internal rejection and danger
posture: sarcastically exposes the futility and self-destructiveness of Judah’s attempts to woo foreign powers or deities
instances.explanation: Zion is personified as a woman dressing up for lovers who now despise and seek her life. This extended metaphor critiques Judah’s vain political and cultic flirtations, using hyperbolic erotic imagery and irony.

deliberation: Two main figures: (1) explicit similes comparing the heard voice to a woman in labor, especially a first-time mother; (2) personification of ‘daughter Zion’ panting, spreading her hands, and speaking a dying lament.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי֩ ק֨וֹל כְּחוֹלָ֜ה שָׁמַ֗עְתִּי צָרָה֙ כְּמַבְכִּירָ֔ה
instances.english_text: I hear a voice as of one in travail, anguish as of a woman bearing her first child
target: the intensity and character of Zion’s suffering and outcry under attack
vehicle: the pains and cries of a woman in labor, especially a first child
ground: both Zion and a woman in labor experience severe, overwhelming pain and gasping cries
posture: conveys the extremity and inevitability of Zion’s distress
instances.explanation: Zion’s cry is likened to the voice of a woman in labor, particularly a first‑time mother, a simile that hyperbolically emphasizes unprecedented, searing anguish.
